data.text: @JimDay22857614 @Naturalcalendar I do believe that. My homemade booze cupboard is very surprising when you dig to the back!

@jpfuller74 @Naturalcalendar All good stuff. Tended to find it all a bit of a faff so when brewing would do so in bulk 4 or 5 demi-johns at a time. Bottled up my last batch 10 years ago as our eldest was toddling & into everything. Would you believe I've STILL got c.24 bottles left for special occasions?!

@JimDay22857614 @Naturalcalendar That’s interesting. I think I used it all for cooking so can’t experiment. It’s impossible to describe the flavour properly….elderflower champagne and crab apple wine are both superb. I’ve also got ten vines ( in Cumbria☔️🌧) and manage to get six bottles of red every year!

@jpfuller74 @Naturalcalendar Gorse flower wine was always one of my favorites to make pre-children, when I had the time & space to do so.

I guess it's not to everyone's taste, but I enjoyed it a lot - although it would often give me the most vivid & surreal dreams in a way that other drinks never have🤔🤪
@Naturalcalendar I was at a permaculture party where we spent two hours dancing to a gorse based rap extravaganza. Wild times. This thread brought it all back. Fantastic. Thank you
@Naturalcalendar Another amazing thread. Thank you so much. Can’t decide which out of  ballochory and myrmechochorus is my new favourite word

@Naturalcalendar I made gorse wine once. Family helped collect the flowers, we all got ripped up hands. Took hours. After carefully brewing and so forth- End product tasted like coconuts, soap and cat urine and some kind of floor cleaner.
@Naturalcalendar Luckily Gorse can keep flowering until you can
